kick.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to hit something with your foot
kick.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: There was a scuffle and he kicked me in the stomach.
kick somebody in the stomach/face/shin etc
Billy was kicking a ball around the yard.
The police kicked the door down.
kick.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to move your legs as if you are kicking something
kick.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He kicked off his shoes and lay back on the bed.
a row of dancers kicking their legs in the air
A horse trotted past, kicking up dust from the road.
kick.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a movement of your foot or leg, usually to hit something with your foot
kick.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Brazil scored with the last kick of the match.
Rory aimed a kick at her leg and missed.
If the door wonâ€™t open, just give it a good kick.
kick.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: the act of kicking the ball in a sports game such as football, or the ball that is kicked and the direction it goes in
kick.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Benjamin struck a post with an overhead kick.
Pearce came forward to take the free kick.
kick.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: something that you enjoy because it is exciting
kick.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Gerald gets a kick out of dressing as a woman.
get a kick out of/from (doing) something
It gives her a kick to get you into trouble.
She used to steal from shops for kicks.
kick.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: The door was stuck; he gave it a kick.
He got a kick on the ankles from Anne.
Lifting her foot, she aimed a kick at her brother.
The only way to make the drinks dispenser work is to give it a good kick.
A hard kick to the knee could cause a lot of damage.
The dance routine was full of high kicks.
